text.*:
The Windsor Beauties are a famous collection of paintings by Sir Peter Lely, painted in the early to mid-1660s.

The name stems from the original location of the collection, which was housed in the Queen's bedchamber in Windsor Castle. They can now be seen at Hampton Court Palace.

Contents

  • 1 The Portraits
  • 2 List of "Beauties"
  • 3 Gallery
  • 4 See also
  • 5 References
  • 6 External links

The Portraits[edit]

The Royal Collection includes 10 portraits as part of the set. They show the women at three-quarter length in various poses. Some women wear current fashions; others are draped in loose robes intended to evoke classical antiquity.

List of "Beauties"[edit]

The original set of "Beauties" painted by Lely include, depending on the source:

  • Frances, Duchess of Richmond and Lennox (née Stuart; 1648-1702)[1][2]
  • Elizabeth, Countess de Grammont (née Hamilton; 1641-1708)[1][2]
  • Jane Myddelton (née Needham; 1646–92)[1][2]
  • Margaret, Lady Denham (née Brooke; c. 1647-67) (named Elizabeth in the cited printed sources [and in 18th century prints] but Margaret at the Royal Collection)[1][2]
  • Frances, Lady Whitmore (née Brooke; died 1690)[1][2]
  • Mary, Countess of Falmouth and Dorset (née Bagot; 1645–79) (named Elizabeth in the cited printed sources [and in 18th century prints] but Mary at the Royal Collection)[1][2]
  • Henrietta, Countess of Rochester (née Boyle; 1646-1687)[1][2]
  • Barbara, Duchess of Cleveland (née Villiers; c. 1641-1709)[1][2]
  • Anne, Countess of Sunderland (née Digby; c. 1646-1715)[1]
  • Elizabeth, Countess of Northumberland (née Wriothesley; 1646-1690)[1][2]
  • Emilia Butler, Countess of Ossory[1] (Melville omits this name, citing Ernest Law that the portrait previously identified by this name is actually Lady Falmouth.)[2]
  • Madame Henrietta, Duchess of Orléans[2]

The portraits for the first 10 names are included at the Royal Collection website as "probably commissioned by Anne Hyde, Duchess of York."

The Duchess of York does not figure in the above list often; but since she was largely responsible for the collection (and choosing the sitters), she was also painted as part of the series. Possibly a little flattery from Lely was responsible for this.

Gallery[edit]

  • Frances Stewart, Duchess of Richmond, before 1662, as Diana

  • Elizabeth Hamilton, Countess of Gramont, c. 1663

  • Jane Needham, Mrs Myddleton, c. 1663-65

  • Margaret Brooke, Lady Denham, c. 1663-65

  • Frances Brooke, Lady Whitmore, c. 1665

  • Mary Bagot, Countess of Falmouth and Dorset, c. 1664-65

  • Henrietta Boyle, Countess of Rochester, c. 1665

  • Barbara Villiers, Duchess of Cleveland, c. 1665, as Minerva

  • Anne Digby, Countess of Sunderland, before 1666

  • Elizabeth Wriothesley, Countess of Northumberland, 1669

  • Henriette, Duchess of Orléans, 1662

  • Anne Hyde, Duchess of York, 1662

See also[edit]

  • Hampton Court Beauties, a later set by Sir Godfrey Kneller
  • Gallery of Beauties, a still later set in Munich

References[edit]

  1. ^ a b c d e f g h i j k Cunningham, Peter (1865). "The Early Painters of England: Peter Lely". The Art Journal. 27 (Vol. 4, New series): 8. 
  2. ^ a b c d e f g h i j k Melville, Lewis (2005). The Windsor Beauties: Ladies of the Court of Charles II (Revised ed.). Ann Arbor: Victorian Heritage Press. pp. i. ISBN 1-932690-13-1.
